node.title: Twitter expands its subscription service to news articles.
node.alt: In June, the company announced Twitter Blue and a plan to charge users a small fee in exchange for extra features.
node.description: The company is pushing to find new sources of revenue.
node.content: ["Twitter said on Tuesday that it would give users access to ad-free articles from The Washington Post, Reuters, BuzzFeed and other publications through its subscription service, called Twitter Blue.", "The offering is part of Twitter\u2019s push to find new sources of revenue. In January, the company acquired Revue, a service that enables people to create newsletters, and said it would take a small percentage of subscription fees from newsletter writers. And in May, Twitter bought Scroll, a subscription company that created ad-free reading services for publishers.", "In June, the company announced Twitter Blue and a plan to charge users a small fee in exchange for extra features like the ability to organize bookmarks and undo tweets. On Tuesday, Twitter said it would ask users to pay $3 a month for those features, as well as access to the ad-free articles.", "\u201cIn continuing our commitment to strengthen and support publishers and a free press, a portion of the revenue from Twitter Blue subscription fees goes directly to publishers within our network,\u201d two Twitter project managers, Sara Beykpour and Smita Gupta, wrote in a blog post. \u201cOur goal is to help each publishing partner make 50 percent more per person than they would\u2019ve made from serving ads to that person.\u201d", "Twitter also said it would revive features associated with Nuzzel, a service offered by Scroll that alerted users about articles that were widely shared by people they followed on Twitter. Twitter shut down Nuzzel when it acquired Scroll, prompting an outcry from users who said the service had helped cut through the noise of their crowded social media feeds.", "The company said it would also grant subscribers early access to new features, allowing them to test products and provide feedback. Twitter Blue is available in the United States, Australia, Canada and New Zealand, Twitter said."]
